article.headline: LSU 65, Southern Miss 50
article.story: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- LSU's defense carried the Tigers on Saturday against Southern Mississippi until Jaime Lloreda heated up to keep the Golden Eagles at bay. Lloreda scored nine of his 15 points in the game's final six minutes, and LSU held USM to 28.6 percent shooting from the field as the Tigers won 65-50. "I think we only played in spurts in this game tonight," LSU coach John Brady said. Lloreda played with six stitches in his left hand after injuring it on Tuesday against Utah. Regardless, he grabbed a game high 16 rebounds for his third double-double of the year. Brandon Bass added 15 points for the Tigers (6-0), who hit just 2-of-23 from the 3-point range. "We've got to get some consistent play from our perimeter," Brady said. "Until we get that consistency, teams will put four guys on our two big guys and force us to hit some 17-footers." LSU shooting guard Antonio Hudson, who scored 10, suffered a sprained left ankle with 3:37 remaining. X-rays showed there was no fracture, but Hudson is doubtful for Tuesday's game against Tulane. Despite its poor shooting, Southern Miss (5-3) made a run midway through the second half and pulled to within 44-41 with 9:58 left on a pair of Clement Carter free throws. USM got double-doubles from Charles Gaines who had 14 points and 12 rebounds and Jasper Johnson with 12 points and 11 rebounds. The Golden Eagles held a 45-38 edge in rebounding. The Tigers extended their six-point halftime lead to 40-29 with 15:40 left on a short jumper by Darrel Mitchell. Southern Miss, which trailed for all except the first 3:22 of the game, began to cut into the LSU lead, whittling it to 44-41 on two Clement Green free throws with 9:59 left. The Golden Eagles had the ball seconds later with a chance to further cut the deficit, but a turnover and back-to-back jumpers by Hudson and a Bass dunk brought the LSU lead to 50-41 with eight minutes left. LSU outscored the Eagles 15-7 in the final minutes. Charles Gaines led the Eagles with 14 points and Jasper Johnson added 12. The Eagles shot just 28.6 percent from the floor (16-for-56) and was outscored by LSU 32-14 in the paint despite holding a 42-35 edge in rebounding.
